8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (22:25): Getting settled?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:25): That remains to be seen
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:26): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: Much packing left?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:26): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Katie is insanely efficient.
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (22:27): To the point where it's more efficient if you just stay out of her way? :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:29): Letting $girl do packing worked quite well when I moved a couple of months back
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:30): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Your girlfriend is variable?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:31): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: Well, I don't expect to have a single girlfriend for my entire life, so yes.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:31): Otherwise breaking-up would be quite hard, if it had been declared as a constant.
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (22:32): wonders if a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554->$girl found out about IRC logs already
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:32): actually it'd be easier, you'd just overwrite the memory location where the value is kept and you'd instantly assign all previous memories to the new girl.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:32): Ah, so functional relationships are like functional languages; single assignment
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:32): and the compiler would be none the wiser
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (22:32): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, also the reasons for breaking up? That seems suboptimal
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:32): well i'm not saying it's optimal
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:32): just that it wouldn't be hard
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:32): (alternative worldview: functional relationships are like functional langauges: optimised for concurrency)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:32): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: in most functional langauges you don't assign per-se.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:33): facepalms
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:33): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: it is possible she has

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:36): in other news, i have a computer with a dead disk. i can dd(1) to it all i want so long as i don't hit the bad parts, but as soon as i hit a bad bit, /dev/sda becomes completely inaccessible to any program. wtf.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:36): (I should maybe point out in the intereests of having a functional relationship that I don't subscribe to the lternative worldview)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:36): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: ain't nothing wrong with polyamoury.

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:37): (and generally agree)

c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6 (22:50): why "blur" event fires when I click on iframe inside the window?
c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6 (22:51): is it possible to prevent it from firing in this situation?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:55): Generally you can't stop events firing, but there is no real need to do anything with the ones you don't want
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:55): Well you can preventDefault of course
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (22:56): preventDefault() doesn't do anything with blur

c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6 (22:59): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: but I need to prevent this event only when iframe inside window is clicked, not when window loses focus to some other window
c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6 (22:59): I have no idea how to do this
c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6 (22:59): as blur event does not provide any information about what causes the blur
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (23:03): c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6: I'm not sure what you are trying to do, but I don't think you can do what you are requesting
